case_vignette: a 55-year-old male with past medical history of jewish ancestry presents with painful oral lesions and few "waterboils" on the arms for the past three months. his only medications include multivitamin and atorvastatin which he has been on for the past 15 years without any dosage changes. he denies any recent travel or genital uclers. a full skin examination is remarkable for irregularly shaped erosions of the buccal and palatine mucosa and scattered flaccid bullae on the arms with few scattered crusted erosions. a biopsy of a bulla on the arm is performed and demonstrates suprabasilar acantholysis with vertically oriented basal keratinocytes with the acantholysis involving hair follicles.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have painful sores in my mouth and some "waterboil" like blisters on my arms.
How long have you had these symptoms?
For the past three months.
Have you experienced any fever, joint pain, or eye irritation along with these symptoms?
No, I haven't experienced any fever, joint pain, or eye irritation.
Do these sores and blisters itch or primarily cause pain?
The sores and blisters primarily cause pain.
Have you been diagnosed with any skin-related or autoimmune conditions in the past?
No, I have not been diagnosed with any skin-related or autoimmune conditions in the past.
Do you have any known allergies to medications, foods, or environmental factors?
No, I don't have any known allergies to medications, foods, or environmental factors.
Do any of your family members have similar symptoms or a history of skin conditions?
I don’t have information about my family members having similar symptoms or a history of skin conditions.
Have the sores in your mouth or blisters on your arms increased in number or size since they first appeared?
No, the sores in my mouth and blisters on my arms have not increased in number or size since they first appeared.
Final Diagnosis: Pemphigus Vulgaris.
